title: Restrooms in the Park
question_text:
A large neighborhood association is considering adding a small restroom building to its three neighborhood parks and will choose a random sample of residents to ask their opinions.
The association decides to sort the neighborhood homes into two groups: those located near one of the parks and those not located near a park. The association will then randomly choose $10\text{ homes}$ from each of those groups.
Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes to guarantee equal representation of opinions from both groups.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes to make the surveys easier to collect.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes because that is a characteristic that could have an effect on people's opinions about the bathrooms.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes so that it can compare the opinions of one group to the other.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes to reduce variability in the difference between the two sample proportions.

solution:
A stratified sample is drawn from a number of separate strata of the population, rather than at random from the whole population, in order to better represent the population.

In this scenario, stratification will lead to a sample that includes houses from all over the neighborhood, which is actually not very easy to collect.

The other choices all describe valid reasons for using a stratified sample.
